numbered_ace_sentences: 1. I notice one thing in the visualization.
2. Young women in the survey tend to be in contact with at least one parent more than young men in the survey.
3. This difference could be due to traditional societal roles.
4. In these roles, society expects that men do not show emotions.
5. In these roles, society expects that men are independent at a younger age than women.
6. Some young men may think that frequent contact with parents makes them seem weak.
7. This belief is not true.
8. I notice another thing in the visualization.
9. Visiting a parent in person is the lowest contact method for young men.
10. Visiting a parent in person is the lowest contact method for young women.
11. This low rate is most likely due to moving away for jobs or college.
12. If a person moves away, then the person cannot visit as much.
13. I wonder how these responses would change by age.
14. The survey asked people who are 18 to 34 years old.
15. The age range is 16 years.
16. A 16-year age range is large.
17. It takes roughly 13 years from kindergarten to the end of high school.
18. I ask whether older respondents are more likely than younger respondents to be in contact with a parent.
19. I ask whether older respondents are less likely than younger respondents to be in contact with a parent.
20. I ask how school location affects the contact status of a respondent.
21. I ask how work situation affects the contact status of a respondent.
22. This graph makes me want to be in contact with my parents more.
23. I am fortunate.
24. I have a good relationship with both parents.
25. I can text my parents easily.
26. I can call my parents easily.
27. I stay in contact with my parents.
28. I do not stay in contact with my parents as often as I think I should.
29. A quick 10-minute conversation would be good.
30. The headline could be: Parental Guidance - How Young Men and Women Differ in Contact with Parents.
